item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. & A.: Adam Minter on Why China’s Scrap Trade Helps the Environment
item.description: Desperate for resources to fuel its fast-growing economy, China has become the world’s biggest importer of garbage: scrap paper, metals, wires and plastic. And while reprocessing discarded electronics and other goods can exact a toll on the environment, recycling can be less polluting than extracting the raw materials from mines, oil wells or forests.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID BARBOZA
item.media:description: A worker carrying a scrapped computer monitor at a waste collection market in Beijing.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Prominent Activist Is Arrested
item.description: Alaa Abd El Fattah, a blogger who rose to prominence in the 2011 revolution, was held Thursday night on charges of inciting a demonstration in defiance of a new law heavily restricting protests, his family said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Bloomberg Code Keeps Articles From Chinese Eyes
item.description: Some stories that Bloomberg runs are considered too sensitive to run in China, raising questions about a clash of journalistic ideals with commercial interests.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Matthew Winkler, the editor in chief of Bloomberg News.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Bloomberg Code Keeps Articles From Chinese Eyes
item.description: Some stories that Bloomberg runs are considered too sensitive to run in China, raising questions about a clash of journalistic ideals with commercial interests.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Matthew Winkler, the editor in chief of Bloomberg News.

item.title: Mixed Legacy for Departing Pakistani Army Chief
item.description: As the taciturn Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani steps down, little has changed in the American-Pakistani relationship despite years of diplomatic effort.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani, the Pakistani Army chief, with Chinese soldiers in Pakistan in 2011.

item.title: At European Meeting on Partnership, Ukraine and Armenia Balk
item.description: The nations’ decision to reject closer ties with Europe has turned a summit meeting partly into a strategy session over how to confront the unexpectedly strong challenge from Moscow.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: President Viktor F. Yanukovich of Ukraine, right, arrived to a chilly reception Thursday at a meeting in Vilnius, Lithuania.

item.title: Secrecy Bill Could Distance Japan From Its Postwar Pacifism
item.description: The bill, which is close to being adopted, and the creation of a security council are prompting fears that Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is pushing the nation backward.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: A protester was removed by security officers after Japan’s lower house of Parliament passed a national secrets act on Tuesday.

item.title: Bangladeshis Build Careers in New York Traffic
item.description: Bangladeshi immigrants are earning a living as traffic enforcement agents in New York, a growing presence navigating the congestion and sea of parked cars.
item.dc:creator: By JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN
item.media:description: Traffic enforcement agents, all immigrants from Bangladesh, on West 34th Street in Manhattan. Hundreds of Bangladeshis have become traffic agents in the last decade, union officials said.

item.title: China Patrols Air Zone Over Disputed Islands
item.description: China sent fighter jets to patrol its newly declared air defense zone after Japan and South Korean military planes flew through it unhindered.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ and MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: A Japanese patrol plane, pictured in 2011, flying over the disputed islands in the East China Sea.

item.title: Ire in Canada Over Report N.S.A. Spied From Ottawa
item.description: Documents leaked by Edward J. Snowden describe surveillance during a summit meeting of world leaders in Canada in June 2010.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Paradela Journal: Hard Times for a Small (and Fuzzy) Group of Europeans
item.description: In an era of austerity, donkeys have been swept up in the debate over just how far the European Union should go to maintain its farming regions.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: João Pedro Marnoto for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gonçalo Domingues, 70, a Portuguese farmer, with his Miranda donkeys.

item.title: Disillusionment Grows Among Syrian Opposition as Fighting Drags On
item.description: More people are turning their backs on the revolt and becoming disaffected by the growing power of Islamists and the disarray, division and greed among rebel commanders.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD, MOHAMMAD GHANNAM and HWAIDA SAAD
item.media:description: A damaged street in Deir al-Zour, Syria. The government of President Bashar al-Assad continues to rack up modest victories.

item.title: Syrian Forces Press Rebels With Gains
item.description: With fighters from Hezbollah, which is based in Lebanon, Syrian government troops gained control of the town of Deir Attiyah, which straddles a critical highway.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Syrian Arab News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Syrian government forces with their national flag in Homs. On Thursday, the forces gained control of a town near a highway.

item.title: Russian-Backed Free-Trade Zone May Expand Its Borders
item.description: The bloc, less tightly woven than the European Union, currently comprises Belarus, Russia and Kazakhstan, and may be joined by at least three more former Soviet states.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Court Grants Bail to Last Detainee in Greenpeace Case
item.description: A court in St. Petersburg granted bail on Thursday to Colin Russell, the last of the 30 people on a Greenpeace International ship seized in September after a protest in the Arctic.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: At Least 29 Are Killed in Attacks
item.description: A series of attacks in Baghdad and in areas to the north and south of the city killed at least 29 people on Thursday, Iraqi officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Malnutrition Persists
item.description: The World Food Program said that North Korea’s food production had increased for the third year in a row but that mothers and children still lacked sufficient vitamins, fat and protein in their diets.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Libya: Deadly Blast at Army Depot
item.description: More than 40 people were killed Thursday in an explosion at an army depot in southern Libya, a security official said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Mali: Fugitive on U.S. List Is Arrested
item.description: Alhassane Ould Mohamed, wanted in the fatal carjacking of an American official in Niger more than a decade ago, has been arrested by French soldiers in northern Mali after he escaped from prison.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Photographs Tell a History of Palestinians Unmoored
item.description: An exhibition of restored photos and film footage compiled by the United Nations Relief and Works Agency documents the history of Palestinian refugees since the 1948 Arab-Israeli war.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: G. Nehmeh/United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:description: An image from 1968 is part of the exhibition of photographs and film footage restored by the United Nations Relief and Works Agency.

item.title: Afghan Leader Lashes Out at U.S. Allies After NATO Drone Strike
item.description: Told that civilians had been killed in at least one drone strike in Afghanistan, President Hamid Karzai indicated again that he would not sign a security agreement.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: President Hamid Karzai at a gathering this week of Afghan leaders whose advice on a security agreement he has rejected.

item.title: A Growth Spurt for Middle Eastern Carriers, Led by Emirates
item.description: Emirates, based in Dubai, is building routes to developing countries, providing an alternative to local carriers and buying a lot of big jets.
item.dc:creator: By JAD MOUAWAD
item.media:description: Emirates has thrived by building routes to developing countries long neglected by traditional carriers.

item.title: Britain Reconsiders Cigarette Regulation
item.description: The government has stepped away from an expected rejection of a proposed set of sweeping restrictions on cigarette packaging aimed at preventing smoking by young people.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Russia Charges Ex-Defense Minister Over a Road Project
item.description: The charges against Anatoly E. Serdyukov reflect a rift in the coterie of officials surrounding President Vladimir V. Putin.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Anatoly E. Serdyukov, right, with Vladimir V. Putin in 2011.

item.title: U.N. Nuclear Inspectors Invited to Iranian Facility
item.description: The invitation to the International Atomic Energy Agency came days after Tehran struck a landmark nuclear deal with world powers.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
